reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Wells novel is full of hope, scandals and the coming of age of Cleo.
reviews.reviewText: I am not one to follow a lot of Windsor royalty, but I love this authors work, so I bought a copy of her latest and I was happy to read this scandalous account of the possibility of a secret daughter of the Prince of Wales. Reminder this is historical fiction.Cleo Davenport has wondered if she was the child of the Prince of Wales. She has heard the gossip. He is the heir to the British throne. She grew up being called “The Princess”.When she turns seventeen she is sent to London to make her debut. She must learn about etiquette, dancing, manners amongst other things that life could offer. Cleo has other plans. She longs to be a jewelry designer for Cartier, and not a life confined to marriage.Wells novel is full of hope, scandals and the coming of age of Cleo.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Interesting story with a twist
reviews.reviewText: Good book with background on WWII. Love the interaction with the Royals.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Very readable, with fine use of historical figures to create interesting fictional tale. If not familiar with the historic Sheppards Hotel in Cairo, we’ll all be researching it. If future editions are published, it would be a treat to see photos of the genuine jewels “owned” by some of the characters as well as sketches of “ Cleo’s “ unique designs.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A novel hard to put down!
reviews.reviewText: Loved all aspects and plots in the book! Having visited Egypt, the book raised many wonderful memories. Worth the read !

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Loved loved this book!! The traveling back & forth from Cario, Paris & England then reading a little about the Prince & Wallis Simpson, jewels, etc! It had a little bit of everything very exciting It kept ur interest throughout the whole book. Totally recommend to all!!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Jewelry, Europe, Wartime
reviews.reviewText: This story was entertaining with twists and turns throughout Europe. While the timeframe includes WWII - and necessarily includes it - the story revolves around jewelry - and what woman is not fascinated by fabulous jewels? Wells' does a great job describing locations and makes it easy to feel you are with Cleo wherever she goes.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Almost Perfect, but Lacks Depth and Detail
reviews.reviewText: There are certain facts we know about Edward VIII, the king who abdicated: for example, Wallis Simpson was not the first time he’d had an affair with someone not considered suitable to be his wife. And, as far as anyone knows, he didn’t have any children with Wallis or any other woman. I could, therefore, reasonably perceive that Cleo would not turn out to be his illegitimate daughter in this novel by Christine Wells before I read the first page.So, if The Royal Windsor Secret wasn’t going to end in a father and daughter reunion, what was it all about? What made me give it four and a half stars?This is an homage to colonial Egypt, which finishes the day the hotel is destroyed. It’s Cleo’s home, a place she yearns to return to despite years of living elsewhere. The book starts (after a prologue) and ends at Shepheard’s. As her life changes, so does life at the hotel. It’s where she meets Brodie, the Scottish boy sent there to live with a relative after his parents are killed. Disowned by his grandfather, he’s treated by some of the residents, including Cleo’s governess, as little more than a servant. It’s also, therefore, a love story as they grow up and their friendship evolves into something else. The semi-fictional story regarding Edward VIII and his former mistress, Marguerite, is woven throughout, along with the love of jewelry that Cleo, Wallis, and Marguerite share. But when does love become obsession?If there’s one disappointment I had with this book, it’s that it felt very shallow on occasion, and there are gaps in the timeline. I was a quarter of the way through it before I realized. I would’ve loved more detail, such as how Cleo adjusted to living in England and more of what she did before World War II. What was the mood like when war was declared? Nor did I really feel the sense of emergency when British forces were trying to leave Cairo ahead of Rommel’s arrival.I’m a harsh marker when it comes to giving stars in a book review. At one point, I had decided The Royal Windsor Secret was only going to receive three stars and I was wondering how to inform the blog tour organizer of which I was part. The lack of depth was a major reason. But I stuck with it, and I urge you to do so as well. Because there’s a very satisfying payoff, right in those final pages. Yes, I would’ve liked an epilogue consisting of a look at Cairo post British rule (did Cleo return?), but I can live without it.Disclaimer: Although I received an electronic copy of this book from the publisher, via Random Things Tours, the opinions above are my own.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This book tells Cleo’s story over 20 years of her life. They are some of the most formative years of her life as she is starting out and becoming an adult in the eyes of society. This book tells the years beautifully and keeps in touch with what would have happened during that time in history. At the end of the book the authors note explains where the inspirations came from and what was more real than fiction. I was fascinated by the entire story. It has strong women, family emotions, and excellent settings. If you are interested in historical fiction, especially centered around the Royal Family, this is a book for you.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 2, 2024
reviews.reviewText: A fantastic historical fiction novel. Well worth a read, I loved this authors style of writing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Who knows what skeletons and secrets the Duke of Windsor had in his closet!
reviews.reviewText: Cleo Davenport grew up at the Shepheard’s Hotel in Cairo, Egypt, she’s been looked after by her guardian Serafina, she’s heard rumours her father is the Prince of Wales and people refer to her as “The Princess.” Cleo and her friend Brodie, have a great time riding horses in the desert and visiting the zoo and have no idea what the future holds for them.An opportunity presents itself a year later for the orphans to travel to England with Lord and Lady Grayson. The journey by sea gives them time to learn their manners, brush up on their social skills and make sure they use the right cutlery. Both Serafina and her sister Lady Grayson think Cleo needs to make her debut, her clothes has aren’t up to scratch, once she arrives in London and Lady Grayson takes her to Paris to get a whole new wardrobe.Cleo visits the Cartier showroom while in the city of lights, she dreams of designing jewellery and working for the master. Cleo want's to solve the mystery surrounding her parentage, she has some information, and she contacts the woman she thinks is her mother and she has a very checkered past!Cleo travels back to London, she can't just walk up to the Prince of Wales and ask him if he's her father, when he's crowned the King of England, he marries divorcee Wallis Simpson, he has no choice but to abdicate and his new royal title is the Duke of Windsor.Chloe goes back to Paris, when the German's invade Poland it becomes too dangerous for her to stay, she returns to London, Chloe joins the FANY’s and she’s sent to Lisbon. Here, Chloe hears talk about the Duke of Windsor and Wallis Simpson being on the Germans side and he's the new British Governor of the Bahamas. Chloe worries about Brodie who's joined Scots Guards, she feels very confused about her feelings for her childhood best friend and why is her life always so complicated?Using the well known theory the Prince of Wales had a relationship with a high class French courtesan during The Great War and she's one of the many women before Wallis Simpson and who knows what skeletons he possibly had hidden away in his closest?The reader is taken on a historical fiction journey and one that you won’t forget in Ms. Well’s latest engrossing and well written narrative. It’s full of interesting details about Cairo, London, Paris and Lisbon and the iconic Shepheard's Hotel and it's famous guests, the intricacies of jewellery design and how it’s made. A story brimming with intrigue, secrets, greed, lies, schemes and I'm not sure who I disliked more Wallis Simpson or French courtesan Marguerite Miller and five stars from me.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Royal Windsor Secret by Christine Wells
reviews.reviewText: Cairo, Egypt 1935: Cleo Davenport, 16 years old, enjoys a life of freedom with her adopted Aunt Serafina and her friend Brodie. Freedom, until her Aunt Serafina gives in to her sister and brother-in-law, Lord and Lady Grayson, when they decide it is time for Cleo to leave Cairo and go with them to London to prepare for her debut into society and presentation to the King, Edward VIII.Left on a doorstep in Cairo as a baby and not knowing her real parentage, Cleo has long lived with the whispers that her real father is none other than the Prince of Wales, now the King. Having no time for ballrooms and debuts, Cleo has the dream of one day designing her own range of jewelry for Cartier.After the King's abdication, Cleo travels to France to follow up on her dream as a designer and also to try to discover her real parentage. Her search takes a shocking turn into the world of the Parisian demimonde and a high-class courtesan, Marguerite Meller.This story takes place between 1934 and 1952 with back stories to 1914, the WWI years and the 1920s.With a mixture of real people and fiction characters, here is insight (though fictional) into the incredible life of Edward and Wallis, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor and I very much enjoyed the interaction between the characters as written by an Author whose work I love.Interesting to learn from the Author's note that the SAS was practically born at the Long Bar at Shepheard's Hotel in Cairo.Very well done, Christine Wells, this story is a winner for me, I loved it.I highly recommend this story and all of Christine's stories to other readers.
This is another of Christine Wells amazing reads. Slowly the story forms and then you can’t put it down. Well worth purchasing
